preface.title: Foreword
preface.para: you are reading the English version of my second Asterisk book. I wrote the book in German and Stephen Bosch translated it into English. He (being an Asterisk professional) also added some North-America specifics. But this book is a project of many people. Ever since the first version it has been published with a FDL licence and more than 100 people contributed by sending bugreports or even by writing new sections. A special thanks goes to my colleage Philipp Kempgen who wrote big chunks for this book. You can find the German edition as per usual at das-asterisk-buch.de and the English version at www.the-asterisk-book.com. Especialy for hardware and driver related stuff (e.g. installing a card and compiling Asterisk for it) I encourage you to have a look at the always up to date online edition.

The last few years have been active ones in the VoIP world. My work with Asterisk has brought me to parts of the world where I haven't been before: Huntsville, Alabama (Digium's headquarter), Toronto, Canada (Sangoma's headquarter) and Bucharest, Romania (Yate's headquarter). I learned much about Asterisk, but also a lot about Yate and FreeSwitch, both interesting open-source VoIP alternatives.

Asterisk has gone quite a way since I installed it first. That very first installation didn't last long on my harddrive because I didn't understand the whole concept of it and documentation was in a good open-source manner (read the source code). But my first linux installation didn't last long on my harddrive either because my MS-DOS way of searching files (entering "dir" and ENTER) did not give any results at all. Today I don't want to miss either of these open-source projects. Linux changed everything for me (I haven't touched a Windows since version 3.11). Asterisk changed my way of thinking about PBXes. Finally a PBX was just a piece of software and not some magic black box on the wall.

But the jump from the old world (black box PBX) to the new world (just software) is one that is critical in many companies. In my daily work as an Asterisk consultant I often see a fight between the former network guys and the former telephony guys which have been seperated for decades and now have to work as a team. I hope to bring both worlds a little bit more together with this book.
I welcome your feedback, praise and criticism. Please send it to me at stefan.wintermeyer@amooma.de.

It has been a special privilege to work with Stefan on the translation of this book into English. As it happens, Stefan speaks English quite well; being the consummate professional that he is, he knew that a competent English version would need a dedicated translator. To be entrusted with this task has been an honor. I was also charged with some of the adaptations and changes for the English edition, including for the chapter on ISDN and for the hardware installation chapter.

Translations are never easy endeavors, but like poetry, a technical translation is a special kind of beast. I hope that the book you have in your hands proves readable and helpful. Like Stefan, I welcome your feedback. Please send it to me at sbosch@vodacomm.ca.
